69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:14): disadvantages include the issues he listed
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:14): like being able to take svg and put it in html and just have it work
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:15): a new disadvantage here is that it would involve breaking compat with shipped browsers
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (01:16): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: the SVG WG says that copy-paste of SVG should work just fine
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:16): the SVG WG says a lot of things
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:16): doesn't mean they're true :-)
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (01:16): sure, but in this case i'd their experience over yours to be honest
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:17): there's plenty of scripts that say &gt; instead of > and similar, deep inside a for loop
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:17): in scripts in SVG or other XML
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (01:18): other XML doesn't matter here
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:18): i'm sure authors would just put up with it if we made it so that such scripts would need changing
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:18): but it _would_ mean that you can't just copy and paste
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (01:18): likewise they'd put up with it if they have to adjust the script when copy-pasting
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:18): also, we'd have to change the CDATA thing
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:18): anyway, as you said earlier, i'm not really the one to convince
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (01:18): i'll chat with henri
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:19): chat with abarth, too

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:20): seriously though, "the SVGWG said so" is no more convincing than &quot 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e said so". if we're going to base this on what is compatible, then we'd need real data.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:20): not heresay or anecdotal evidence.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:20): (another difference would be comment parsing inside scripts, i wonder how many svg files have commented-out content in <script> blocks)
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (01:21): well.. i suspect that the SVG WG has a lot more experience looking at the markup that various tools output
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (01:21): and so far most of the SVG which is generated, is generated using tools i bet
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (01:22): usually inkscape, sometimes Illustrator
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (01:23): I'm not convinced that just dropping SVG into HTML would necessarily work
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (01:23): especially when scripts are involved
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (01:23): since the DOM will be very different
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (01:23): not even all SVG content generated by Inkscape or Illustrator works in browsers
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (01:23): the <svg> element won't be the documentElement for example
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (01:24): yes, a lot of SVG with script assumes that SVG is the root
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (01:24): not sure who said it would just work...
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:24): c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059: we've tried quite hard to make it so the DOM differences are minimised
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (01:24): but I'm on the SVG WG, and I'm not at all confident about that

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:25): c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059: btw i commented on the bug. i agree that it's a potential security risk, and i think henri underplays the risk. hopefully my comment will help.

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:26): 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6: when we first started working on adding svg parsing in html, the svg wg's most ardent request was that it be possible to take raw SVG files and paste them into text/html without modifications and have the parser handle it exactly as if it was SVG in XML

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:27): 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6: a number of reasons were given, such as making sure that errors made in editing SVG in HTML wouldn't be accepted and thus "corrupt" the pristine SVG ecosystem, and making it possible for output from SVG tools could be dropped straight into HTML files without work.
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (01:27): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: yes, I think that was a reasonable request
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (01:27): I don't know for a fact that that was accomplished, either in the HTML5 spec or in implementations
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:28): at least the second part of that is only reasonable if one is confident that SVG content dropped into HTML would in fact just work

227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (01:28): there's also author education around how to write the script correctly such that it doesn't break‚Ä¶ but that's not really an authoring tool issue, unfortunately‚Ä¶ not many good tools for scripting SVG
